This i® Graham Hovey, sending from Home a second letter from Italy con-
coming the political crisis that came with the fall of the government of
Premier Giuseppe Pella* These programs are produced for the national Associ*

In the first of these two radio letters on the Italian political crisis
I tried to Indicate why a showdown between Premier Pella and hi® own Chris¬
tian Democratic party probably would have come eventually even if it had bee:
averted for the present.
Pella has never been what politicians call "a party man;’* he had never
been the party * s choice for prime minister| and he was unwilling to accept
the party’s veto of hi a choice for agriculture minister of & man who had
opposed the party1® land reform program.
Bat l added, in that first Letter devoted to the subject, that the fall
of aella was Just a symptom of a deeper and broader political crisis which
today grips all Italian democratic parties, but especially the Christian
Democrats. And today I should like to examine that deeper and broader crlsi
as it affects Italy’s biggest partyi the party that has had the primary re¬
sponsibility for governing the country for more than eight critical postwar
years.
I should emphasise again that these lines are being recorded in advance
of the designation of a new premier by Italy’s president, Luigi Einaudt* 3u
the analysis of the crisis in the Christian Democratic party may help explai
what happened to Pella and some of the difficulties that probably will con¬
front hi® successor.
X said that this deeper and broader crisis affects all Italian democra¬
tic parties.
I might add that I had prepared part of a series of letters from Italy,
examining the current situations of these parties, before the present crisis
broke. And I was waiting only for the Pella cabinet to be reorganized befor
examining the position of the Christian Democrats. X believe that in spite
of the changed situation caused by the fall of Pella, those previously-pre¬
pared analyses will stand up. But if you hear them you should keep In mind
that I had no crystal ball and that they were prepared in advance of Pella’s
resignation on January 5*
To Europeans accustomed to party unity and responsibility, Italy’s
Christian Democrats make little sense. And even to Americans, accustomed to
a Democratic party broad enough to cover Harry S. Truman and Harry P. Byrd,
or a Eepublican party heterogeneous enough to embrace Senator George Aiken o
Vermont on one hand and senator John Brisker of Ohio on the other — even to
u®, the Christian Democracy is an astonishing coalition*
A couple of years ago an American Journalist, Leo J* Wallenberg, des¬
cribed the Christian Democratic party as *’a rainbow with a spectrum ranging
all the way from a faint pink to a Fascist black, or at least gray. And an*
Italian writer has referred to the party as "a very peculiar and treacherous
organism." It is, said this writer, "an amalgam of a mass party, a politics
